questions.article: The Gleaners, painted in the realist style by Jean-François Millet, depicts peasants picking stray wheat from a field after the harvest. The realists' emphasis on accurately portraying the experiences of average working people was largely a rejection of the romantic style evident in many paintings by Paul Delaroche, which instead ______ their subjects' beauty or heroism while hiding all imperfection.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: mock

options.name: B
options.content: exaggerate

options.name: C
options.content: correct

options.name: D
options.content: undermine

questions.correct: exaggerate

questions.article: The minor planet 1061 Paeonia was named after the plant genus that includes peonies. But most minor planets are given only an identification number, largely due to there being over 500,000 such bodies known at present. So while the task of finding a unique name for each minor planet was ______ when few had been discovered, so many minor planets have since been discovered that the task has become nearly impossible.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: substantial

options.name: B
options.content: insurmountable

options.name: C
options.content: feasible

options.name: D
options.content: ambiguous

questions.correct: feasible

questions.article: The term "agglomeration economies" refers to the economic benefits enjoyed by firms in the same industry that ______ in a region. For example, in the computer manufacturing industry in the United Kingdom, firms that locate near one another can more readily take advantage of increased potential for information sharing among firms that fosters greater technological innovation.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: recur

options.name: B
options.content: dissipate

options.name: C
options.content: concentrate

options.name: D
options.content: terminate

questions.correct: concentrate

questions.article: In the decades after Mexico won its independence from Spain, literature became a medium through which the new nation ______ its autonomous identity, with authors like Manuel Payno and Justo Sierra Méndez helping to shape what would become a distinctly Mexican literary tradition.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: overcame

options.name: B
options.content: realized

options.name: C
options.content: decried

options.name: D
options.content: evaded

questions.correct: realized

questions.article: Researchers examining data from the New Horizons space probe, which passed Pluto in 2015, were puzzled by a 27-mile-long crater on Pluto's icy surface. Although Pluto is mostly covered in frozen methane and nitrogen, the surface near the crater seemed to show the presence of water ice and ammonia—both of which are associated with eruptions from ice volcanoes. Additionally, the shape and appearance of the crater did not suggest that it was formed by impact. Based on this evidence, scientist Dale Cruikshank and his team hypothesized that the crater was likely once a massive ice volcano.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It introduces previous findings that suggested a research method for Cruikshank and his team.

options.name: B
options.content: It implies that the research team eliminated an alternative explanation for the crater based on available evidence.

options.name: C
options.content: It emphasizes the importance of the New Horizons space probe to researchers.

options.name: D
options.content: It identifies a misconception that the researchers had about the crater when they were first studying the data.

questions.correct: It implies that the research team eliminated an alternative explanation for the crater based on available evidence.

questions.article:
Text 1
In the past, music albums were created to be played back on physical formats like records. A typical record holds only about twenty-five minutes of music on each of its shiny black sides. This forced artists and producers to think carefully about what music to include on an album and what to leave out. Today's artists don't have to worry as much about fitting their music on physical formats. For this reason, many of today's artists are making albums that are much longer than albums from decades past.

Text 2
In today's digital age, most music is created to be streamed from online services. These services remove the limitations of physical formats like records and CDs. This may be why many new albums are longer and have more songs than albums crafted for physical formats. Unfortunately, many of these longer albums suffer from a lack of focus.
questions.question: Based on the texts, the author of Text 1 and the author of Text 2 would most likely agree with which statement about many new albums?

options.name: A
options.content: Many new albums include more artwork than albums generally once included.

options.name: B
options.content: Many new albums sell more copies than albums generally once sold.

options.name: C
options.content: Many new albums are longer than albums generally once were.

options.name: D
options.content: Many new albums are quieter than albums generally once were.

questions.correct: Many new albums are longer than albums generally once were.

questions.article: It has long been thought that the original author of the US Pledge of Allegiance was Francis Bellamy, who said that he wrote the pledge one evening in August of 1892. But a historian recently discovered a newspaper article that was published several months before August 1892. The article describes students reciting the same pledge that Bellamy claims he first wrote in August. This means that Bellamy may not have created the pledge after all.
questions.question: Based on the text, what piece of knowledge about the Pledge of Allegiance has recently become uncertain?

options.name: A
options.content: How many changes were made to the pledge in the 1900s.

options.name: B
options.content: Which part of the pledge students liked best in 1892.

options.name: C
options.content: The name of the newspaper that first published the pledge.

options.name: D
options.content: The identity of the person who first wrote the pledge.

questions.correct: The identity of the person who first wrote the pledge.

questions.article: Sheep and macaque monkeys can see in three dimensions (3D), which helps them perceive distance and depth. Octopuses and squid are thought to lack 3D vision. Many researchers once thought the same about cuttlefish, but Trevor Wardill and his team wanted to test whether this assumption was true. The team studied how cuttlefish wearing 3D glasses reacted to 3D images of shrimp (a favorite prey) projected on a tank wall. Cuttlefish changed their striking position to match the 3D images, suggesting that their vision is more like that of sheep and macaque monkeys than that of octopuses or squid.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Cuttlefish eyes are much more complex than those of either sheep or macaque monkeys.

options.name: B
options.content: Before completing their study, Wardill's team showed that sheep have 3D vision, but macaque monkeys may not.

options.name: C
options.content: Wardill's team designed 3D glasses for cuttlefish.

options.name: D
options.content: The findings of Wardill's team's study suggest that like sheep and macaque monkeys, cuttlefish may also have 3D vision.

questions.correct: The findings of Wardill's team's study suggest that like sheep and macaque monkeys, cuttlefish may also have 3D vision.

questions.article:
The following text is from Anthony Trollope's 1855 novel The Warden. Tom Towers is a writer for the newspaper The Jupiter.

It is true that in far-off provinces men did not talk daily of Tom Towers but they read The Jupiter, and acknowledged that without The Jupiter life was not worth having. This kind of hidden but still conscious glory suited the nature of the man. He loved to sit silent in a corner of his club and listen to the loud chattering of politicians, and to think how they all were in his power;--how he could smite the loudest of them, were it worth his while to raise his pen for such a purpose.
questions.question: What does the text most strongly suggest about Tom Towers?

options.name: A
options.content: He has received much praise but tends to place too much value on his own importance.

options.name: B
options.content: He takes private satisfaction in his capacity to influence public opinion.

options.name: C
options.content: He aims mainly to win the regard of readers who reside in other provinces.

options.name: D
options.content: He flatters himself that his readers take a greater interest in him than in politicians.

questions.correct: He takes private satisfaction in his capacity to influence public opinion.

questions.article: Life Among the Paiutes is an 1882 autobiographical narrative by Sarah Winnemucca Hopkins, a Northern Paiute author, educator, and activist. In the work, Winnemucca directly addresses the reader to explain certain customs, writing ______
questions.question: Which quotation from Life Among the Paiutes most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: "During the time my grandfather was away in California, where he [stayed] till after the Mexican war, there was a girl-baby born in our family."

options.name: B
options.content: "Now, my dear reader, there is no word so endearing as the word father, and that is why [my people] call all good people father or mother."

options.name: C
options.content: "But how can I describe the scene that followed? Some of you, dear readers, can imagine."

options.name: D
options.content: "We would all go in company to see if the flowers we were named for were yet in bloom, for almost all the girls are named for flowers."

questions.correct: "Now, my dear reader, there is no word so endearing as the word father, and that is why [my people] call all good people father or mother."

questions.article: Researchers Carolina Laura Morales and Anna Traveset gathered data about flowering plants growing alongside each other in various locations. In each case, the researchers identified one plant as a "target species" and a nearby plant as a "neighboring species." The researchers then calculated a value to show how the neighboring species affected pollinator visits to the target species. The table shows that the Himalayan balsam had an effect value of ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the example?

questions.article: The nearly forty tribes located in Oklahoma, including the Chickasaw Nation and the Seminole Nation, operate numerous businesses and generate billions of dollars in revenue. A student in an economics class is researching the tribes' collective activity as a single industry. The student wants to compare that industry's contribution to Oklahoma's overall economy in 2017 with the contributions made by three other industries in the state. Looking at the table, the student finds that tribal economic activity totaled over $7.3 billion, ranking it above ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the comparison?

options.name: A
options.content: both accommodation/food services and retail but below health care.

options.name: B
options.content: accommodation/food services but below both health care and retail.

options.name: C
options.content: health care, retail, and accommodation/food services.

options.name: D
options.content: accommodation/food services and nearly equal to health care and retail.

questions.correct: accommodation/food services but below both health care and retail.

questions.article: Assessing the role of forests as sinks for airborne microplastics that would otherwise continue to disperse in the atmosphere, Akane Miyazaki and her team measured concentrations of plastic particulates on leaves from konara oak trees in Japan. The team used three separate extraction methods: an ultrapure water rinse, a rinse combined with ultrasonic waves, and an alkaline solution treatment that removes epicuticular wax (a surface coating on most land plants to which particles can adhere). The concentrations of particulates recovered were 7.6 percent for water extraction, 38.4 percent for ultrasonic extraction, and 53.8 percent for alkaline extraction, leading the team to conclude that previous assessments have likely underestimated forest canopies' capacity as sinks.
questions.question: Which detail, if true, would most directly support the team's conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: Most studies of microplastic accumulation on leaves have utilized extraction methods that do not have a substantial effect on epicuticular wax.

options.name: B
options.content: Most studies of microplastic accumulation on leaves have focused on forests with diverse tree species that exhibit varying levels of epicuticular wax.

options.name: C
options.content: Most studies of microplastic accumulation on leaves have found particulate concentrations that greatly exceeded 53.8 percent.

options.name: D
options.content: Most studies of microplastic accumulation on leaves have involved the application of alkaline treatments before water and ultrasonic treatments rather than after them.

questions.correct: Most studies of microplastic accumulation on leaves have utilized extraction methods that do not have a substantial effect on epicuticular wax.

questions.article: Mariana Lopes Barata and Pedro Simões Coelho collected data from 324 music-streaming service users to identify factors that influence users to opt for paid (premium) versions of music streaming services, like Apple Music. They hypothesized that hedonic motivation (the enjoyment that a consumer perceives to be associated with using a service) would be positively correlated with users' intentions to adopt premium versions. The researchers asked participants to rate statements such as "Using paid music streaming services is pleasant." They found that, indeed, hedonic motivation positively influences the intention to adopt premium streaming service versions, which suggests that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: it may be advantageous for music streaming companies to try to influence the extent to which potential users perceive the premium version as pleasant to use.

options.name: B
options.content: participants who strongly agreed with the statement "Using paid music streaming services is pleasant" were more likely to express loyalty to Apple Music than to other streaming services.

options.name: C
options.content: the statement "Using paid music streaming services is pleasant" is not a reliable measure of hedonic motivation.

options.name: D
options.content: users' intentions to pay for premium streaming services are probably unaffected by factors other than hedonic motivation.

questions.correct: it may be advantageous for music streaming companies to try to influence the extent to which potential users perceive the premium version as pleasant to use.

questions.article: On August 15, 2013, the Navajo Times ______ a profile of Manuelito Chapter (Kin Hózhóní), which is one of the 110 chapters of the Navajo Nation (Naabeehó Bináhásdzo). The article was later included in a book series called Exploring the Navajo Nation Chapter by Chapter.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: will publish

options.name: B
options.content: published

options.name: C
options.content: publishes

options.name: D
options.content: is publishing

questions.correct: published

questions.article: According to the original text of the US Constitution, written in 1787, the presidential candidate receiving the second-most Electoral College votes becomes vice president. The 12th amendment, ratified in ______ separated the elections for the two offices.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: The colors of Navajo (Diné) weaver Melissa Cody's work World Traveler (2014) recall both the Germantown revival, a weaving style developed by Navajo Nation ______ ago, and the color palette of the video games that Cody played as a child.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: artist's over 160 year's

options.name: B
options.content: artists over 160 years'

options.name: C
options.content: artists' over 160 years

options.name: D
options.content: artists over 160 years

questions.correct: artists over 160 years

questions.article: The editors of Home Ground: A Guide to the American Landscape turned to Luis Alberto Urrea, a poet, to craft the entry for "atarque," a term referring to a watering hole formed by a natural or artificial dam. For "muskeg," however, the editors chose the ______ author of Of Landscape and Longing.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: essayist Carolyn Servid

options.name: B
options.content: essayist, Carolyn Servid

options.name: C
options.content: essayist Carolyn Servid,

options.name: D
options.content: essayist, Carolyn Servid,

questions.correct: essayist Carolyn Servid,

questions.article: A groundbreaking visual artist of her day, ______ including artists Vasily Kandinsky and Piet Mondrian.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: Hilma af Klint, well before many of her contemporaries, explored abstract modes of painting,

options.name: B
options.content: Hilma af Klint explored abstract modes of painting well before many of her contemporaries,

options.name: C
options.content: well before many of her contemporaries, Hilma af Klint explored abstract modes of painting,

options.name: D
options.content: the explorations of Hilma af Klint into abstract modes of painting occured well before those of many of her contemporaries,

questions.correct: Hilma af Klint explored abstract modes of painting well before many of her contemporaries,

questions.article: The small celestial body known as 2010 BL4 is expected to have a relatively short lifetime in the outer solar system. Within just a few million years, 2010 BL4 is likely to migrate into the inner solar system or be destroyed, according to ______ trajectory.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: astronomers modeling of the objects

options.name: B
options.content: astronomer's modeling of the object's

options.name: C
options.content: astronomers' modeling of the object's

options.name: D
options.content: astronomers modeling of the object's

questions.correct: astronomers' modeling of the object's

questions.article: Many works of the Roman scholar Varro (1st century BCE), including his history of Rome, De gente populi Romani, have been lost to time. Scholars wishing to read a work written by the Roman scholar needn't ______ they can still procure a copy of Varro's Rerum rusticarum libra tres, a treatise on agriculture.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: despair, though

options.name: B
options.content: despair, though,

options.name: C
options.content: despair, though;

options.name: D
options.content: despair—though

questions.correct: despair, though;

questions.article: Using LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) technology, Tulane University archaeologists scanned and mapped the ancient Mayan city of Tikal, which lies deep in the Guatemalan rainforest. Some of Tikal's old stones are intertwined with the roots of surrounding trees, rendering parts of the complex physically inaccessible to researchers. ______ the LiDAR's penetrating light waves were the only way to reveal some previously unknown aspects of the Mayan city.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Similarly,

options.name: B
options.content: Afterward,

options.name: C
options.content: Hence,

options.name: D
options.content: Specifically,

questions.correct: Hence,

questions.article: Imagine a magazine that a reader has thrown away. This magazine is post-consumer waste, as it became waste after reaching the consumer. ______ the paper scraps left over from printing the magazine are pre-consumer waste, as they became waste before reaching the consumer.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: For example,

options.name: B
options.content: Specifically,

options.name: C
options.content: By contrast,

options.name: D
options.content: As a result,

questions.correct: By contrast,

questions.article: One proposed boundary between Earth's atmosphere and outer space is the Kármán line, 100 km above sea level. Based on the work of physicist Theodore von Kármán, this line marks the theoretical height at which an aircraft no longer remains aloft using the force of lift. ______ an aircraft sustains flight past this altitude primarily by its velocity, reaching a speed sufficient to maintain an orbit but not to generate enough lift from the thin air.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Regardless,

options.name: B
options.content: For instance,

options.name: C
options.content: Granted,

options.name: D
options.content: Instead,

questions.correct: Instead,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture is a research library in New York City.
  • It was named for Arturo Alfonso Schomburg.
  • It was founded in 1925.
questions.question: The student wants to indicate the year the Schomburg Center was founded. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The Schomburg Center was named for Arturo Alfonso Schomburg.

options.name: B
options.content: The Schomburg Center is a research library.

options.name: C
options.content: The Schomburg Center was founded in 1925.

options.name: D
options.content: The Schomburg Center is located in New York City.

questions.correct: The Schomburg Center was founded in 1925.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Brussels sprouts are vegetables that contain ascorbic acid, an essential nutrient for humans.
  • Apples are fruits that contain ascorbic acid.
  • There is 80 milligrams (mg) of ascorbic acid in every 100 grams (g) of brussels sprouts.
  • There is 6 mg of ascorbic acid in every 100 g of apple.
  • Humans cannot make ascorbic acid in their bodies, so they must get it from foods, including fruits and vegetables.
  • Ascorbic acid is also known as vitamin C.
questions.question: The student wants to compare the vitamin C content of brussels sprouts and apples. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Brussels sprouts contain vitamin C (also known as ascorbic acid)—80 mg in every 100 g, to be exact.

options.name: B
options.content: Brussels sprouts and apples both contain vitamin C, but brussels sprouts contain more.

options.name: C
options.content: Brussels sprouts are vegetables, and apples are fruits.

options.name: D
options.content: Humans cannot make ascorbic acid in their bodies, but they can get it from brussels sprouts.

questions.correct: Brussels sprouts and apples both contain vitamin C, but brussels sprouts contain more.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Merle Oberon (1911–1979) was an actress born in Mumbai (then known as Bombay), India.
  • She was of Indian, Maori, and Irish heritage.
  • She was the first Indian-born actress to be nominated for an Academy Award.
  • Early in her career, she played many nameless, uncredited roles, such as her role in The Three Passions (1928).
  • Later, she played many named, credited roles, such as Empress Josephine in Désirée (1954).
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a similarity between the two films. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The Three Passions and Désirée are both films that include Merle Oberon, the first Indian-born actress to be nominated for an Academy Award.

options.name: B
options.content: The Three Passions (1928) was released early in actress Merle Oberon's career, whereas Désirée (1954) came out later.

options.name: C
options.content: In The Three Passions (1928), actress Merle Oberon played a nameless, uncredited role; however, in Désirée (1954), she played a credited role—that of Empress Josephine.

options.name: D
options.content: Early in her career, Merle Oberon wasn't listed in some film credits, such as the credits for the film The Three Passions, where she played a nameless, uncredited role.

questions.correct: The Three Passions and Désirée are both films that include Merle Oberon, the first Indian-born actress to be nominated for an Academy Award.
